turn.2: With flowing pleats from the shoulders was originally an undress fashion.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: At its most informal, this gown was unfitted both front and back and called a "sacque".
turn.6: With a more relaxed style came a shift away from heavy fabrics, such as satin and velvet, to Indian cotton, silks and damasks.
turn.7: Any other interesting information you can tell me?
turn.8: Also, these gowns were often made in lighter pastel shades that gave off a warm, graceful and childlike appearance.
turn.10: Later, for formal wear, the front was fitted to the body by means of a tightly-laced underbodice, while the back fell in loose box pleats called "Watteau pleats" from their appearance in the paintings of Antoine Watteau.
turn.12: The less formal "robe à l'anglaise", Close-bodied gown or "nightgown" also had a pleated back, but the pleats were sewn down to fit the bodice to the body to the waist.
